content.description:
Clear the approach climbing at the bottom, following the right of the two branches. Use turbo buckets to pull over the first overlap and gain a wide stem rest. From here it's all about pump management as you pull a series of mini-boulders, each of which are followed by a mini-rest. 

This train of mini-boulders is capped with a more substantial boulder over a high roof. Pull this to gain a rest in the corner at the top. One last nasty surprise over the lip (and also a bolt)!

Powerful, pumpy, and excellent movement! Rivals Dreams be Dreams for best line on the wall!

Long draw the first bolt (mostly a redirect for your belayer) and back clean your second. 



Locate the belay block towards the right end of the wall, under/left of the big overhang/cave feature. This line starts from the right of the two belay bolts, and follows the right most bolt line (branching right off of Dreams be Dreams after 3 shared bolts). 

12 bolts, fixed anchor with biners.

This climb breaks into two distinct sections; the start which features a boulder problem and then several meters of climbing where the holds face sideways or are crack like (requiring lots of horizontal movement and careful body positioning). Then you reach a ledge and it's time to bucket slam! 

Until the small surprise at the lip...

The bolting is a bit awkward, the bolts are fairly evenly spaced up the line, so don't expect there to always be a comfortable clipping hold! Back clean the first bolt. 



Locate the line right of the small cave and immediately left of the Last Banana (yellow hangers). This line has a fairly prominent left facing corner ~20 m off the deck (you don't actually climb the corner). 

12 bolts, fixed anchor with biners.

Banana Bypass shares the first 3 bolts with Last Banana (look for yellow hangers), then traverses right for 4 bolts over steepening terrain. The final 7 bolts negotiate a corner system and a few roofs. This near perfect route is respected as one of Skaha's best at the grade!  
  
 Due to the traversing nature of the route, consider either having a follower clean on top rope, or cleaning first half while lowering and cleaning the bottom half on top rope to minimize the swing.

Look for the yellow hangers of Last Banana.  Shares the first 3 bolts then trends right on a different line of bolts.
14 bolts, anchor with chains.

Climb your way through the technical bottom to get to the cave. Clip two bolts that are close together so you don't deck, pull the lip, and fight the rope drag to the top. 

Belay below the ledge in front of some poison ivy
14 bolts with anchor

Easily the best route on the wall, despite Banana Bypass getting all the attention. Located in the big, overhanging ampitheater on the right side of the Maternal Wall, this beauty climbs up the center of it. Great climbing with three distinct cruxes (including a heartbreaker at the top if you read it wrong) and safe falls if you blow it. Get on it!

Start up the furthest right bolt line on the ledge of Banana Wall, but go straight (stay left) when the line splits.
11 bolts (fixed as of 2014), anchor.

A series of mini cruxes with a couple good rests with overall great climbing. 

Look for the yellow hangers just to the left of the popular Banana Bypass (11c sport).
11 bolts

Climb onto the ledge to clip your first bolt. Reach right for a bucket to gain the bulge and awkwardly pull up to clip your second bolt. Now you can start climbing!

Three bolts of very sustained, very interesting climbing where you end up nearly horizontal on at least 2 occasions gets you to a hidden permadraw. At this point, you're onto the Banana Bypass link, so you know it's over! 

Finish out the remaining 20 m of excellent victory climbing



Aim for the overhanging, big cave feature towards the right end of the wall. Hop up on the big belay boulder. This line goes straight up from the left of the two belay bolts. 

13 bolts, fixed anchor (rap rings)

This route is an interesting one and like many of the routes at the Maternal Wall, it climbs much different than most other walls in the bluffs. I guess this is the warm-up, but have your head screwed on as it is balancy, slopey, has some scary clips and is very long. A full set of skills is very helpful for this one.


On the Banana Wall at Maternal Wall, this route starts up a left-facing flake/feature system two routes left of Last Banana/Banana Bypass (yellow hangers). Starts above the right edge of the small cave. 

13 bolts (the book is wrong), anchor.

This route has seen a major change since Richardson's 2012 book was published, which originally had it graded at 11a. Because of large loose blocks at the top of the route, the two first bolts after the midway anchor have had their hangers removed to discourage climbers from continuing upwards. The route now effectively ends at the anchor below the steep blocks, bringing the grade to 10c.

Fun technical Skaha style climbing wander past 7 bolts.

At the left end of the wall
Draws

Climb slippery rock to establish yourself on the wall. Boulder to the left across the slab at the 4th bolt (long draw) and then climb through vertical terrain until you reach a ledge (right of the tree). A final steep boulder problem guards the anchor at the lip. 

There is a higher anchor, it did not seem reasonable at the grade to continue to it. 

Consider stick clipping, the first hold feels friable. 



On the far left of Maternal there is a belay block up behind a couple of large tree's. This line starts off the right edge of this block and follows the maroon coloured hangers. 

9 bolts, fixed anchor with biners.

This tall and steep crag boasts some of skaha's more pumpy sporty routes, most maxing out a full 60 meter rope. The upper half of the crag consists of wonderful roofs while the lower half involves rare skaha slopers.  
  
 Home to some classic 4 star anywhere 11+ /12- routes 
 Also offers AM shade as the crag faces west.
